item.title: Stop Computer Networking
item.description: While I was following the Kubernetes The Hard Way on the laptop with Vagrant VMs, I was reminded of the conviction that I had been holding: an application generally should not deal with computer networking. That is, it should not concern with host addresses or ports or HTTP protocols or anything. Instead, it should work above a messaging abstraction provided by message brokers like NATS or Kafka or such. If the application requires low network latency such as video streaming, then it would need to deal with networking.

item.title: Home network v1
item.description: It was long overdue I learned the basics of IP networking, and there wouldn’t be a better way than to learn it hands-on by setting up my own home network. Before then, I’d been using the same WiFi hub installed by the ISP when I moved in. (By the way, if you are using the WiFi hub installed by D’Live, be aware that it exposes the configuration UI on port 8080 to the Internet.
